articles.headline: Wells Fargo C.E.O. Timothy Sloan Abruptly Steps Down
articles.snippet: Mr. Sloan took over as chief in 2016 as the bank dealt with the fallout of a series of scandals. C. Allen Parker was named the interim chief executive.
articles.abstract: Mr. Sloan took over as chief in 2016 as the bank dealt with the fallout of a series of scandals. C. Allen Parker was named the interim chief executive.
articles.lead_paragraph: Timothy J. Sloan, the embattled chief executive of Wells Fargo, abruptly stepped down on Thursday as one of the country’s largest banks struggles to recover from a series of self-inflicted scandals.
articles.byline: By Emily Flitter, Stacy Cowley and David Enrich

articles.headline: In This Tech I.P.O. Wave, Big Investors Grab More of the Gains
articles.snippet: Unicorns like Lyft are finally going public, after large gains have been captured by elite early investors.
articles.abstract: Unicorns like Lyft are finally going public, after large gains have been captured by elite early investors.
articles.lead_paragraph: The latest generation of Silicon Valley start-ups is now sprinting to the public markets, raising hopes among large and small investors eager to invest in these high-profile, fast-growing firms.
articles.byline: By Matt Phillips and Erin Griffith

articles.headline: Inside the Tensions at Carlos Ghosn’s Nissan
articles.snippet: Once seen as a model of global cooperation, the Nissan-Renault alliance seethed with fear and rivalries, raising questions about its future.
articles.abstract: Once seen as a model of global cooperation, the Nissan-Renault alliance seethed with fear and rivalries, raising questions about its future.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — It was 2011, and Carlos Ghosn was preparing his automotive empire for its most ambitious phase yet. Under his plan, within five years, one of every 12 cars sold around the world would be made by Nissan of Japan. To achieve that goal and cut costs relentlessly, he said, Nissan would have to work closely with Renault, the French automaker he also controlled.

articles.headline: They Let a Sick Inmate Die in a Van. Now They Won’t Pay His Family $650,000.
articles.snippet: The prisoner transport business has a poor safety record. Here’s how one company has dodged responsibility in the death of an inmate.
articles.abstract: The prisoner transport business has a poor safety record. Here’s how one company has dodged responsibility in the death of an inmate.
articles.lead_paragraph: Johnny Smith spent almost 24 hours shackled in the back of a prison van — barely conscious and muttering incoherently — before he died there in 2011. A private company was hauling Mr. Smith, 48, to Florida from Kentucky to face a drug charge: possession of a single oxycodone pill.
articles.byline: By Alysia Santo and Eli Hager

articles.headline: When Joe Biden Voted to Let States Overturn Roe v. Wade
articles.snippet: Mr. Biden voted for a constitutional amendment to allow individual states to overturn Roe in 1982, then later voted against it. His back-and-forth over abortion has been a hallmark of his career.
articles.abstract: Mr. Biden voted for a constitutional amendment to allow individual states to overturn Roe in 1982, then later voted against it. His back-and-forth over abortion has been a hallmark of his career.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was a new era in Washington in 1981, and abortion rights activists were terrified.

articles.headline: A Texan’s Big Bet on a Fossil-Fuel Future for California
articles.snippet: Andrew Beal, a poker-playing billionaire and major Trump backer, could upend California’s carbon-free power goals with a case before federal regulators.
articles.abstract: Andrew Beal, a poker-playing billionaire and major Trump backer, could upend California’s carbon-free power goals with a case before federal regulators.
articles.lead_paragraph: California has positioned itself as a leader in the fight against climate change. It leads the nation by far in solar power. And it is working to reduce carbon emissions throughout the energy sector, with a goal of making the electricity grid carbon-free within a generation.
articles.byline: By Ivan Penn and Thomas Kaplan

articles.headline: How Sovereign Citizens Helped Swindle $1 Billion From the Government They Disavow
articles.snippet: Tens of thousands of far-right extremists subscribe to a paranoid ideology that lends itself seamlessly to financial crime.
articles.abstract: Tens of thousands of far-right extremists subscribe to a paranoid ideology that lends itself seamlessly to financial crime.
articles.lead_paragraph: One day in 2015, Barbara Lavender’s husband returned from a U.F.O. conference and handed her a business card. It bore a red theater-curtain background, a vintage microphone and gold-and-white lettering that read: “Sean David Morton, Radio Host, Public Speaker, Author, Director, Screen Writer, Actor.” The polymathic Mr. Morton, Jeff Lavender told his wife, was U.F.O. royalty.

articles.headline: Lyft’s Shares Jump in Trading Debut, Cementing Rise of the Gig Economy
articles.snippet: An I.P.O. underscored the depth of investor hunger for fast-growing young tech businesses, even if they are deeply unprofitable.
articles.abstract: An I.P.O. underscored the depth of investor hunger for fast-growing young tech businesses, even if they are deeply unprofitable.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Owning a piece of the gig economy became a reality for millions on Friday when Lyft began trading on the public markets, signaling the start of a stream of stock offerings expected from high-profile technology companies this year.
articles.byline: By Kate Conger and Michael J. de la Merced
